meanings.definition: To act as an escort or companion to someone, especially a woman.
meanings.sent1: He esquired his sister to the party to make sure she was safe.
meanings.sent2: The gentleman esquired the lady to the theater for the evening.
meanings.sent3: The young man esquired his grandmother around the garden, making sure she didn't trip.
meanings.sent4: The loyal dog esquired the little girl through the forest, protecting her from any harm.
meanings.sent5: She felt like a princess as he esquired her through the crowded ballroom.

meanings.definition: To serve as a squire or attendant to a knight.
meanings.sent1: The young page esquired the knight, carrying his armor and sword.
meanings.sent2: In the medieval times, it was an honor to be esquired to a noble knight.
meanings.sent3: The squire esquired the knight to the jousting tournament, making sure his armor was polished.
meanings.sent4: He esquired the knight through the battlefield, ready to assist in any combat.
meanings.sent5: The loyal squire esquired his master with unwavering dedication and loyalty.

meanings.definition: To act as a chaperone or protector.
meanings.sent1: The bodyguard esquired the celebrity through the crowd of fans.
meanings.sent2: She esquired her little brother to the playground, watching over him carefully.
meanings.sent3: The security guard esquired the valuable painting to the museum, ensuring its safety.
meanings.sent4: The guardian angel esquired the child through the dangerous streets, keeping them out of harm's way.
meanings.sent5: The knight esquired the princess through the treacherous forest, shielding her from any danger.
